tweets.text: Ugh, #rstats transition to newer LAPACK in R 4.2.x and 4.3.0 have altered SVD somehow such that Koopman DMD no longer works. Release notes reference "some sign changes" in SVD, but it's worse than that. Doing the trivial calculation for KDMD outputs wrong answer. https://t.co/mFwRTcARpo

7/ üìö Resources üìå 
To learn more about the caret package, check out the official documentation: https://t.co/M4TJ4uRXrN & Max Kuhn's book "Applied Predictive Modeling." üìñ #RStats #DataScience

6/ üîç Model Comparison üìå 
Compare model performance using resamples() and summary(). With these functions, you can easily identify the best-performing model & select the most suitable one for your problem.ü•á #RStats #DataScience

5/ üèóÔ∏è Model Training üìå 
Train multiple models with ease using the train() function. caret allows for grid search, random search, or Bayesian optimization for hyperparameter tuning. üéõÔ∏è #RStats #DataScience

4/ üß© Resampling Techniques üìå 
caret provides various resampling techniques, like k-fold cross-validation, to assess model performance. Use the trainControl() function to specify your desired method.üîÑ #RStats #DataScience

3/ ‚öôÔ∏è Feature Selection üìå 
Use the rfe() function for recursive feature elimination. This method helps you find the most important features in your dataset, improving model performance & interpretation.üåü #RStats #DataScience

2/ üßπ Data Pre-processing üìå 
caret offers various data pre-processing techniques, like centering, scaling, and removing near-zero-variance predictors. Use the preProcess() function to apply these methods before model training.üß™ #RStats #DataScience

1/ üéØ Introduction üìå 
The #caret package in #R is a powerful tool for data pre-processing, feature selection, and machine learning model training. In this thread, we'll explore some useful tips & tricks to help you get the most out of caret. #DataScience #MachineLearning #RStats https://t.co/W8CWwpDwN1

7/üåßÔ∏è Cons of #sweave:
‚ùå Limited output formats (mainly PDF)
‚ùå No syntax highlighting for code chunks
‚ùå No caching mechanism
‚ùå Limited customizability
‚ùå Lacks support for other languages
‚ùå Reduced integration with RStudio
These limitations have led to a shift towards #knitr.

5/üî¨ #sweave is the original package for creating dynamic reports in R. Developed by Friedrich Leisch, it's been around for longer and is more mature. However, it has some limitations compared to #knitr, especially in terms of output formats and flexibility. #Rstats

4/üåßÔ∏è Cons of #knitr:
‚ùå Slightly steeper learning curve
‚ùå Can be slower with large data sets
‚ùå Some compatibility issues with older #sweave documents
‚ùå More dependencies, which could lead to potential conflicts
Despite these drawbacks, it's still the preferred choice for many

2/üîç #knitr is a more recent and widely-used package that simplifies the creation of dynamic reports. It's an evolution of #sweave and supports various output formats, including PDF, HTML, and Word. Plus, it's compatible with Markdown and LaTeX! #Rstats

1/üß∂üìù Welcome to a Twitter thread discussing the pros & cons of the #R packages, #knitr and #sweave. These packages allow us to create dynamic, reproducible documents that integrate text, code, and results. Let's dive into the strengths and weaknesses of each. #Rstats

Excited to kick off the 2nd edition of #MultivariateDataAnalysis with #Rstats and #vegan with @ucfagls üöÄ
Let's dive deeper into analyzing complex data sets and uncover hidden patterns. üìäüìà
#DataScience #Statistics https://t.co/EZSkJNbtwn

tweets.text: üß™8/9 Bonus: If you are using hierarchical clustering methods, you can use the 'dynamicTreeCut' R package to find the optimal number of clusters by cutting the dendrogram at the most suitable height. #RStats #DataScience https://t.co/04tByXf3jO

urls.title: dynamicTreeCut: Methods for Detection of Clusters in Hierarchical Clustering Dendrograms
urls.description: Contains methods for detection of clusters in hierarchical clustering dendrograms.

tweets.text: üß†7/9 Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) & Akaike Information Criterion (AIC): Both BIC & AIC are model selection criteria that help identify the optimal number of clusters by balancing the model complexity and goodness-of-fit. #RStats #DataScience https://t.co/LH3E4tSJ8K

üí°6/9 Consensus Clustering: This method combines multiple clustering runs with varying numbers of clusters to identify the most stable partitioning of the data. The optimal number of clusters is chosen based on the stability of the partitions. https://t.co/nnOgu619fV

urls.title: ConsensusClusterPlus
urls.description: algorithm for determining cluster count and membership by stability evidence in unsupervised analysis

tweets.text: üåà4/9 Gap Statistic: The Gap Statistic method compares the total within-cluster sum of squares (WSS) with that of a null reference distribution. The optimal number of clusters is found when the gap is the largest. R package: 'cluster' and 'factoextra' #RStats  #DataScience

üìà3/9 Silhouette Score: This method evaluates the quality of clustering by calculating the average silhouette score of each data point. Higher silhouette scores indicate better cluster assignments. Optimal clusters have the highest average silhouette score.https://t.co/iHUKAdMi1v

urls.title: cluster: "Finding Groups in Data": Cluster Analysis Extended Rousseeuw et al.
urls.description: Methods for Cluster analysis. Much extended the original from Peter Rousseeuw, Anja Struyf and Mia Hubert, based on Kaufman and Rousseeuw (1990) "Finding Groups in Data".

urls.title: index.knit
urls.description: Maps allow us to easily convey spatial information. Here, we show how to create both static and interactive maps by using several mapping packages including ggplot2, leaflet, mapview, and tmap. We create maps of areal data using several functions and parameters of the mapping packages. Then, we show how to create maps of flows among locations with the flowmapblue package. The areal data we map correspond to sudden infant deaths in in the counties of North Carolina, USA, in 1974 and 1979 which are in the

urls.title: Facilitate Citation of R Packages
urls.description: Facilitates the citation of R packages used in analysis projects. Scans project for packages used, gets their citations, and produces a document with citations in the preferred bibliography format, ready to be pasted into reports or manuscripts. Alternatively, grateful can be used directly within an R Markdown or Quarto document.

4. Finally, evaluate the model on the test set:
test_predicted_labels <- knn(train_data[, -5], test_data[, -5], train_data[, 5], k = best_k)
test_accuracy <- sum(test_predicted_labels == test_data[, 5]) / nrow(test_data)
cat("Test accuracy =", test_accuracy, "\n")

#RStats

# Loop through the k values and evaluate the model on the validation set
for (k in k_values) {
predicted_labels <- knn(train_data[, -5], validation_data[, -5], train_data[, 5], k = k)
accuracy <- sum(predicted_labels == validation_data[, 5]) / nrow(validation_data)

#RStats

library(class)

k_values <- c(1, 3, 5, 7, 9) # Define a range of k values for tuning
best_k <- k_values[1]
best_accuracy <- 0

#RStats #DataScience

3. Now you can train a model using the training set and tune its hyperparameters using the validation set. For instance, let's train a simple k-Nearest Neighbors (kNN) classifier using the class library:

# Define the sizes of the data splits
train_size <- 0.6 * nrow(iris_shuffled)
validation_size <- 0.2 * nrow(iris_shuffled)

#RStats #DataScience

2. Now, let's shuffle the dataset and split it into training, validation, and test sets (60%, 20%, and 20% respectively):

set.seed(42) # Set a seed for reproducibility
iris_shuffled <- iris %>% sample_frac(1)

#RStats

Let's demonstrate the process of splitting the data into training, validation, and test sets using R. We'll use the iris dataset, which is built into R, for this example.

1. First, let's load the necessary libraries and the iris dataset:

library(dplyr) 
data(iris)

#RStats

üßµ7/7 To sum up, understanding the distinction between test and validation sets is crucial for building effective and generalizable machine learning models. They serve different purposes in the model development process, and maintaining their independence is key. #DataScienceü§ñüéì

üßµ5/7 It's important to maintain the independence between these sets. Repeatedly using the test set to make model adjustments can lead to overfitting, as the model will start to perform well on the test set specifically, but may not generalize well to new data. #RStats

üßµ4/7 Differences: 
üîπPurpose: Validate set fine-tunes model, test set for final assessment. 
üîπUsage: Validate set in model dev stage, test set used post-finalization. 
üîπImpact: Validate set directly affects model, test set doesn't impact. #RStats #DataScience

üßµ3/7 Test set: This is a separate dataset not used during model training or validation. It's only used after the model has been finalized to assess its performance on completely unseen data. This provides an unbiased evaluation of the final model. #RStats #DataScience

üßµ2/7 Validation set: It is used during model development to tune hyperparameters and make decisions about the model architecture. It helps evaluate the model's performance and prevents overfitting by providing an unbiased estimate of how well the model generalizes to new data.

Now, let's consider a model with a parameter p (probability of heads) and compute the likelihood for the observed data.
